name: tap water production, seawater reverse osmosis, ultrafiltration pretreatment, baseline module, single stage | tap water | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/11940/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of drinking water (potable water) water from seawater reverse osmosis with ultrafiltration pretreatment using baseline membrane modules and a single stage configuration. Baseline membrane is a polyamide membrane of 35.3 m2 of active membrane surface and maximum operating pressure of 1000 psig (69 bars).  This dataset is based on published literature and on modeling. Reverse osmosis system was modeled using typical seawater characterisation, single stage baseline module membrane system with recovery rate of 40% and energy recovery by pressure exchanger of 40%. It includes water intake of seawater, ultrafiltration pretreatment, reverse osmosis filtration, recarbonisation and emissions of brine to sea. The modeling of the reverse osmosis treatment was done using the ROSA (Reverse Osmosis System Analysis) system design software from Dow Chemical. Recarbonation and post-treatment of permeate water are modeled with the Rothberg, Tamburini and Winsor (RTW) Model for Corrosion Control and Process Chemistry 4.0 by Tetra Tech. Typical seawater characterisation for salinity of 3.5% (w/w) was used for modeling. Composition is based on literature (Open University 1989). ;Open University (1989). Seawater: its composition, properties and behaviour. Gerry Bearman Editor, Pergamon Press, 165p.

From intake of seawater. This dataset includes energy and material inputs for the different water treatment stages: chlorination, coagulation, ultrafiltration, dechlorination, reverse osmosis membrane filtration and post-treatment. It includes material for the membrane module and pressure vessel assuming lifetimes of 5 and 15 years, respectively.

This dataset ends with the production of tap water, at facility gate. Electricity for lighting and heating the building  is excluded due to lack of data. Note that the energy for the pumps pressurizing water at the beginning of the network was estimated due to lack of data. It excludes energy for pumping stations and water losses within the network which is included in the tap water market. Emissions to the environment are limited to release of brine to the environment and carbon dioxide emissions from water under atmospheric conditions.
category: E:Water supply; sewerage, waste management and remediation activities/36:Water collection, treatment and supply/360:Water collection, treatment and supply/3600:Water collection, treatment and supply

processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Model represents seawater reverse osmosis system with conventional pretreatment using baseline membrane modules and a single stage configuration and is used to represent actual tap water production using this technologie.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: This dataset is based on published literature and on modeling.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Mass of ion returned to the ocean with the concentrate as calculated by modeling for seawater reverse osmosis with conventional pretreatment considering single stage baseline 8-inch spiral wound modules using ROSA system design software (Dow Chemical). Note that the impact from emission of concentrate reside mostly in the high ion loaded water and small area of release which individual substance emissions will not be well acounted by impact models.

Note that the impact from emission of concentrate reside mostly in the high ion loaded water and small area of release which individual substance emissions will not be well acounted by impact models.

exchanges.description:
Literature value. Sum of chemical use for water pretreatment and backwash of membrane based on  Al-sarkal, T. et al. 2013 and Biswas, W. K. (2009).  

Al-Sarkal, T., & Arafat, H. a. (2013). Ultrafiltration versus sedimentation-based pretreatment in Fujairah-1 RO plant: Environmental impact study. Desalination, 317, 55-66. 

Biswas, W. K. (2009). Life Cycle Assessment of Seawater Desalinization in Western Australia, 369-375.
